This supersedes IRM 8.2.3 dated August 6,

John V. Cardone Director, Policy Quality and Case Support

Whipsaw and Inactive Cases
) This section covers general procedural guidelines pertaining to cases that related, contain whipsaw issues and are in an inactive status. to Related, (

) Related cases involve a common or similar issue such as different years of same taxpayer received at different times, or cases of the same taxpayer Various involving different kinds of tax received at the same or different times. Generally, related cases are classified either as “interrelated cases” or related cases”. (

) “Interrelated cases,” are those in which a determination with respect to an issue in one case has a direct tax effect in another case. Examples a. amount or distribution of net income of a partnership, estate, or trust; b. gift versus compensation from a corporation to widow of a deceased employee; c. value of goodwill in sale of a going business. (

) “Other related cases” refers to related cases, other than “interrelated where there is consistency in the settlement of common or similar issues in cases, but the determination in one case does not have a direct tax effect another case. Examples include: a. taxability of dividends paid on corporate stock; b. indefinite versus temporary character of employment of a number of taxpayers at a single location; c. taxability of amounts received by State police for cost of meals. (
) Compliance usually forwards all interrelated cases together when sending them to Appeals. (

) The number of other related cases transferred to Appeals depends upon pliance’s overall objectives and their determination of the desirability of consistent action with respect to the similar or common issue. (

) In some circumstances, a case may be closed rather than sent to Appeals be associated with related cases. Ordinarily other related cases are not requested from Compliance unless it appears securing these returns is necessary to produce consistency. If this occurs, the ATE will contact the Territory Manager to discuss what actions each function will take with to the scope of the Service’s consideration. (

) In general, the ATE considers small cases on the basis of the record and does not request that Compliance develop further evidence, examine returns, conduct re-examinations, or furnish additional information. This to small cases that are classified as interrelated or other related cases. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

“Interrelated cases,” are those in which a determination with respect to an issue in one case has a direct tax effect in another case. Examples include:
(10-01-2012) Appeals Consideration of Related Cases

In some circumstances, a case may be closed rather than sent to Appeals to be associated with related cases. Ordinarily other related cases are not requested from Compliance unless it appears securing these returns is necessary to produce consistency. If this occurs, the ATE will contact the Territory Manager to discuss what actions each function will take with respect to the scope of the Service’s consideration.
Pre
-Day and
-Day (

) The ATE generally accepts Compliance’s determination that adjustments either not feasible or not required in the related cases. The fact the ATE’s termination is inconsistent with returns filed or action taken in small related cases, such as where duplicate dependency exemptions are claimed, does influence the ATE’s decision in the case. Any resulting action that needs to taken as a result of the ATE’s decision on the case is a function of Compli- ance. (

) No attempt is made to define the terms “material” and “small cases,” since they vary with the factual circumstances. The terms are not interpreted in a narrow or restricted sense, but broadly enough to secure the objectives intended. (
) If related cases are under concurrent consideration by different Appeals there must be communication between the offices during consideration of cases to ensure consistent actions are taken. (

) Circumstances may occasionally require inconsistent positions in cases where not all of the taxpayers are agreeable to a settlement to the Government or are unwilling to have their cases considered by Appeals. (
) Appeals considers principal cases without requesting additional related when Compliance forwards principal cases to Appeals following applicable Consideration procedures. Cases (

) When a partner files a return in an Area other than where the partnership Related Cases return is filed, advance approval is granted to transfer the partner’s case to Appeals Office serving the Area where the partnership return is filed. gives high priority to principal cases. (

) Appeals informs Compliance of significant developments on principal cases they occur and furnishes a complete status report to Compliance on cases on the tenth day of January, April, July, and October. (

) Usually, all interrelated cases needed for consideration of an issue are forwarded together to Appeals by the Operating Unit Field Territory Consideration Occasionally, the ATE determines from the facts and nature of the issue that Cases there are interrelated cases not in Appeals. (
) The best overall use of Service resources and the avoidance of whipsaw tions is the primary considerations in deciding whether such cases are assembled and considered concurrently. IRM

) Some cases might be returned to the originating office as premature In other instances, Appeals retains the case while the originating office completes action on the interrelated cases so they can be considered with the cases already before Appeals. (

) If the Revenue Agent’s Report (RAR) does not contain information about related case, the ATE will contact the Revenue Agent to ask the location status of the interrelated case. However, Policy Statement P–

restricts reopening of cases previously closed by Compliance. If interrelated cases under consideration in more than one Appeals office, the ATE must their determinations. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Whipsaw and Inactive Cases

) This subsection discusses cases involving carrybacks, including cases the carryback arises from a year that is under Appeals jurisdiction and Cases Involving where the carryback exists before the case is received in Appeals. (
) It also covers procedures related to potential Joint Committee cases. (
) When a taxpayer files a claim ( Form
, Form
X, Form

X) to carryback a loss, a credit or some other type statutory carryback, or when to Cases taxpayer receives a tentative carryback allowance for a year included in a Appeals under Appeals jurisdiction and Compliance has completed examination of case which contained the loss year producing the carryback, the ATE will request a copy of the final Revenue Agent’s Report (RAR) to ensure the correct deduction or credit amount is included in the settlement computation the case in Appeals jurisdiction. (

) When a tentative allowance was allowed and Compliance has the case for examination of the loss year to determine the correct carryback amount waiting for them to resolve their case would substantially delay closing the Appeals case, Appeals closes it’s case on an agreed basis subject to eration of the carryback amounts at a later date once determined by Compliance. These procedures also apply when the Appeals case is subject Joint Committee procedures. See IRM

, Joint Committee Case Proce- dures. a. Include a statement similar to the following in the closing letter: “The tentative allowance is subject to correction upon determination of correct amount of the carryback.” b. Include a statement on Form
, Appeals Transmittal and Case randum, informing Compliance that action is required with respect to year creating the carryback. (

) Appeals may, with the concurrence of the taxpayer, assume jurisdiction in a related case without a protest, after Compliance completes any necessary in action. Without (

) If the need for an additional interrelated case becomes apparent after a ence is held, Appeals must contact the related taxpayer. In the absence of objection, Appeals assumes jurisdiction after requesting Compliance any actions needed. (

) When an Appeals settlement affects the taxpayer’s liability for other years the tax liability of a related taxpayer not under Appeals’ jurisdiction, notify Follow-Up pliance so appropriate follow-up action may be taken at their discretion. on (

) The Appeals Case Memorandum (ACM) will discuss subsequent year or and include a clear and concise discussion of the impact in the conclusion element of the ACM or attachments. Example: Basis adjustment – Include depreciation schedules.
8.2 Pre 90-Day and 90-Day
Example: Basis adjustment – Include depreciation schedules.
Example: Carryback adjustments – schedule showing corrected use of the carryback and years affected.

) In certain instances, resolution of a tax dispute may require incorporating an adjustment into a tax year not currently before Appeals in which a Revenue Agent’s Report (RAR) has not been issued. Examples of situations requiring Years such action include the disallowance or allowance of tax shelter losses and rollover adjustments resulting from a prior year. Once it is determined such adjustment is appropriate, make an effort to determine whether any further action by Appeals is permissible. (

) In instances where an RAR was not issued with respect to a year affected an Appeals settlement, determine if the tax return for the affected year is currently under examination. a. If the affected year is not under examination, and the statute of has not expired, notify the Compliance function (which ordinarily has diction over the related taxpayer) of the proposed action and allow them an opportunity to comment. b. Where there is no pending case on the related taxpayer (and none planned), prepare, for the benefit of Compliance, a Form

, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo, containing the appropriate adjustments for the affected year. c. Under certain circumstances (when deemed appropriate by the ATE and agreed to by an Appeals Team Manager (ATM)) proceed with a of the affected year by using either Form

or a restricted Form after first updating the taxpayer’s affected year to the AIMS database. d. If the affected year is currently under the jurisdiction of another IRS contact that office so appropriate action can be taken by Appeals to resolve the issue by having the taxpayer provide Appeals with an amended return for the affected year based upon the adjustments to year’s tax liability. Immediately forward the amended return to the appro- priate Campus and process any payments made by the taxpayer with return. e. In the event the statute of limitations has expired for the affected year to the filing of an amended return, consult with Area Counsel before pro- ceeding with a settlement of the case if offsetting adjustments are made involving the years in issue. (

) When an Appeals office has information indicating examination of a return currently under examination would be in the best interest of the Service, to Appeals sends a memorandum describing the facts to the Operating Unit Territory Manager when Compliance is unaware of the information received Appeals.

currently under examination. a. Where there is no pending case on the related taxpayer (and none planned), prepare, for the benefit of Compliance, a Form

, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo, containing the appropriate adjustments for the affected year. c. Under certain circumstances (when deemed appropriate by the ATE and agreed to by an Appeals Team Manager (ATM)) proceed with a settlement of the affected year by using either Form
or a restricted Form

-AD after first updating the taxpayer’s affected year to the AIMS database. d. If the affected year is currently under the jurisdiction of another IRS office, contact that office so appropriate action can be taken by Appeals to resolve the issue by having the taxpayer provide Appeals with an amended return for the affected year based upon the adjustments to that year’s tax liability. Immediately forward the amended return to the appro- priate Campus and process any payments made by the taxpayer with this return. e. In the event the statute of limitations has expired for the affected year prior to the filing of an amended return, consult with Area Counsel before pro- ceeding with a settlement of the case if offsetting adjustments are made involving the years in issue.

When an Appeals office has information indicating examination of a return not currently under examination would be in the best interest of the Service, Appeals sends a memorandum describing the facts to the Operating Unit Field Territory Manager when Compliance is unaware of the information received by Appeals.
(10-23-2007) Information Report to Compliance

Territory Manager when Compliance is unaware of the information received by Appeals. The best overall use of Service resources and the avoidance of whipsaw tions are the primary considerations in deciding whether interrelated cases are assembled and considered concurrently. Interrelated cases are those in which a determination with respect to an issue in one case has a direct tax effect on another case. A small related or interrelated case is ordinarily considered on the basis of the record and requests are not made for Compliance to develop further evidence
Pre
-Day and
-Day (
) An determination inconsistent with action taken in another small case must influence the ATE. Any further action in a related case must be taken by pliance. (
) Settlements in related cases should not be made when a party is clearly not liable under the facts but agrees to a deficiency of a related taxpayer. (
) No settlement offer will be accepted by Appeals where there is a related in Counsel unless both offices agree the offer is acceptable. When There (

) Disagreements between Appeals and Counsel on whether a settlement offer a Related Docketed should be accepted will be resolved by Area Counsel, with the advice and sistance of the Appeals Area Director and the Associate Chief Counsel responsible for the issue. (
) Counsel reviews proposed Appeals Notices of Deficiency, claim and final adverse letters for any case related to a docketed case; (
) For information pertaining to refund suits on related Appeals cases, see IRM
Suits on Related Cases (

) In related cases the taxpayers may want an overassessment to offset a defi- ciency. This is accomplished by adding a paragraph to the agreement form of reads similar to the following: in Related The undersigned taxpayer also consents and agrees to the application of that of the overassessment that represents an overpayment, and interest allowable thereon, as a credit to the deficiency, in tax of $ , and interest thereon, due from (related taxpayer) for the year ; provided the amount of any overpayment and interest allowable thereon that is in excess of the deficiency and interest is otherwise credited or refunded in accordance with section
of the Internal Revenue Code, or corresponding provisions of prior laws. (
) Also make appropriate notation in Remarks section of Form
, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo and Form
, Appeals Closing Record. (
) Adjustments sometimes increase the tax liability of one taxpayer, but for sistency require a reduction in the tax liability of another taxpayer. (

) Service policy requires delaying the closing of a case with an From until the taxpayer in an interrelated case with a deficiency agrees to the to a Related proposed adjustments or a court establishes the correctness of the adjust- ments. See Policy Statement P–
in IRM
) If the period of limitation for filing a claim is about to expire, give the taxpayer with the proposed overassessment written advice to file a tective claim.

) A whipsaw situation develops when a settlement in one case can have a contrary tax effect in another case and one of the taxpayers may later, the period of limitations applicable to the other case has expired or is expire, file a claim on a basis inconsistent with the prior closing. (
) Another whipsaw situation develops when a related party achieves a determination inconsistent with a result already determined by the Service another related party. (

) Additional action may be necessary in order to protect the Government’s interest in a whipsaw situation. a. If a material amount of tax is involved and there are litigating the use of a closing agreement is ordinarily warranted. b. In the absence of circumstances stated in (a) above, a collateral agreement is obtained if it is considered useful to express in writing understanding of the parties. However, a collateral agreement does have the legal effect of a closing agreement. c. For use of closing agreements and collateral agreements in related see IRM
, Closing Agreements. (
) Appeals cases are classified as “active” or “inactive” for case processing control purposes. “Inactive” category includes those placed in “suspense” status. (

) Inactive cases includes cases where: a. One case, ordinarily referred to as key case, will be litigated to decide issue common to a group of cases - such as groups involving trusts beneficiaries, partnerships and partners, small business corporations stockholders, etc.; b. Issues in the case are litigated in another case and proper disposition the case under consideration is precluded until the litigated case is decided; c. Criminal prosecution is pending or under consideration in the particular case, in other years, or in a related case (see IRM

, Cases Involving Criminal Prosecution and Restrictions on Appeals Jurisdiction Criminal Case); d. Taxpayer is involved in litigation with respect to certain property rights rights to income which need to be concluded before taxable income be determined; (

) In cases involving some of the above examples, it may be advisable, depending on local practice, to notify Compliance or Counsel for the the case is in inactive status. Compliance and Counsel can then determine possible effect the Appeals action has on similar or related pending cases. (
) A work unit is defined as a unique grouping of one or more related cases being considered for settlement or decision purposed. on ACDS (

) When multiple cases are assigned to a work unit, there must be one case ignated as the “key case”. Enter related cases first and the key case last because this enables the system to add all case dollars together and show correct total on the key case. (cid:

) KEYTP (Key Taxpayer Case of the Work Unit) - If the case is the key leave this item blank. If the case is a related case, enter the name of the key case in this field create a related record within the same work unit. (

) TFRCorp (Trust Fund Recover Corp Name) - Name of the Trust Fund poration related to the taxpayer. (cid:

e. An Appeals office requests technical advice or information from ters or was advised by Headquarters that the Service’s position on the issue is under consideration; f. In cases involving some of the above examples, it may be advisable, depending on local practice, to notify Compliance or Counsel for the reasons the case is in inactive status. Compliance and Counsel can then determine the possible effect the Appeals action has on similar or related pending cases.
